We had the opportunity to dine at Le Mont for my belated birthday dinner. My birthday is always during winter restaurant week. This was my first restaurant week experience because for whatever reason, we never took advantage of it.

I made reservations via open table about a week in advance. My actual birthday (Friday) didn't have too many reservations left (only 9pm) so we decided on Sunday dinner here. 

I am going to agree with other reviewers and say that you pay for the view. Food and service are okay, but for the hype and (regular) price of entrees, I just expected things to be better. 

I ordered off of the restaurant week menu. Honestly, Le Mont had a good pre fixe compared to other places. I went with the stuffed sole. It was stuffed with crab and almonds.  I got to choose soup or salad (salad) and a dessert (strawberry shortcake). The server assistant brought out bread for us. While appreciated, the bread was oddly very salty.. like pretzel salt. Thankfully the poppy seed bread made up for it. My salad was initially served with the wrong dressing and I had to send it back. 

My boyfriend didn't care for the pre fixe menu ordered from regular dinner menu. He went with the duck. It is marinated In raspberry vinaigrette and cooked. afterwards more vinaigrette is placed on it. The dish was absolutely amazing and I highly recommend it. It put my stuffed sole to shame, lol. 

The sides for our dishes were mashed potatoes and veggies (carrots, asparagus). The mashed potatoes were extremely dry, unseasoned and very bland (think instant mashed potato flakes and water!) It was disappointing. At first I thought they were just slacking since I was using a pre fixe menu, but my boyfriend $45 entrée was served with the same basic potatoes.

My strawberry shortcake was delicious. We also bought a bottle of wine. 

While the view and duck entrée were amazing, everything else was pretty basic, including service. Don't get me wrong, she did an good job, but I guess I was just expecting to be "wow'd" more since its a fancier place. The hostess basically ran to seat us at our table instead of kindly asking us how we are doing or making sure we were even caught up with her. (ive been a hostess at chain restaurant and fancy wine bars so I know how to professionally greet & seat guests.. I just expected more courtesy I suppose)

overall the experience was fun, but for the price there are better places out there, especially on Grandview.

It's important to preface this review with two caveats: first, remember that you're in Pittsburgh. Second, understand that largely the restaurant location, not the food, is what you're really aiming to experience. 

That's not to say the food is bad; it isn't! But it's also not extraordinarily creative or adventurous. Each entree is served alongside mashed potatoes and vegetables, and is plated in a similar fashion to the others.

However, there are many good things about this restaurant: the food is good. I enjoyed it tremendously. The service was excellent as well, very attentive and knowledgeable. My steak was prepared perfectly, and the lobster I had was broiled exceptionally well. Oh, and the view - well, it's hard to beat.

If you're looking for a good place for a nice dinner in Pittsburgh, consider giving this place a try. It's not the best, but in the city where people dine out the least in all of America, it passes muster and gets the job done.

Extremely pricey but delicious food and amazing view. Definitely worth trying once. One thing I did find weird though is that our checks all came with two spots to tip - one for our server and another for the maitra d.

Lobster bisque - 4 stars
Three berry spinach salad - 4 stars
Cafe de Peris (filet and crab mix) - 2 stars
Pineapples foster - 4 stars
Creme brûlée - 4 stars
Service - 3 stars
View of city and interior design - 5 stars

Too bad that the entree was a bland 2 stars. Based on its taste, I probably will not return.

Went to Lemont during restaurant week. This was my first time eating at a restaurant on Mt. Washington but it appears that you are paying for the view. The food was good and the restaurant was classy and beautiful but I was not extremely impressed. Our waiter was older and the service was nothing to talk about. My husband ordered steak which was made tableside but it was slightly overcooked and sat for about 10 minutes before any of our food was even served.

My family and I dined at Le Mont last weekend and our experience exceeded all expectations! From the spectacular view, delicious appetizers and entrees, and wonderful service by our waitress Beth, our group couldn't have been happier! Manager Danni was very gracious and checked on our table often to make sure everything was perfect. Highly recommend!
Great service and great scenery but food was unimpressive and bland. Definitely not worth the price. My wife and I both had fish dishes so maybe it's a steak joint

This was my first visit to Le Mont. I came for a Yelp Elite event. We were given a 3 course meal with wine. For my first course, I had the soup of the day. It was a nice light soup. I also had a poppy seed roll. I love bread, so I loved the roll. 

For my second course, I had the almond crusted salmon. The salmon was very, very delicious. The salmon was cooked perfectly, not overcooked and dry like it can often be. It came with a side of mashed potatoes , and steamed mixed vegetables. 

The the dessert course, I ordered the funnel cake. I was excited about the funnel cake, although I did think it was a little of an odd choice for the rest of the menu. Nevertheless, I ordered it because I only get it once a year. Sadly, I wasn't all that thrilled with it. It was very, very hard. Funnel cake is normally soft and pliable. This was hard as a rock. I didn't enjoy it.

The decor is definitely styled for old-money. It's gold and gaudy, but palatable.

The manager mentioned that they have a 3-course special periodically for I believe $33 a person. If you are looking for a good dinner and a great view, I'd recommend Le Mont.

FOOD - Their lamb is fantastic. Everything else was average or above average. I also loved their cocktails, but their lobster bisque was too thick and salty and their stuffed pepper was too plain. The only thing I didnt like about the place was their valentine days menu. Other than then, I was never really unhappy walking out of Le Mont.

SERVICE - Good service! Fast, nice and friendly.

AMBIANCE - very formal. The view is amazing. You should call earlier to reserve a table nearby the window. The whole place looks like 19th century and is very romantic. Its very quiet in there so probably not the best place for kids, but it is a really good place for couples, soon to be couples, families, or for big groups in special events.

OVERALL - Le Mont is probably one of the best restaurants amongst the ones on Mt. Washington(I've been to 5 restaurants on mt washington).

My wife and I got married here in 1994.  We go back on our anniversary each year (Yes,20+ years).  After this years visit, I simply can't ignore the poor service and overpriced, tasteless entrees any longer.  Ever since this restaurant changed hands years ago (over a decade), it has consistently gone down hill year after year.   Aside from the mushroom soup, our meals were barely edible this time.  Stale cold bread to start.  Had to beg waitress for drinks no service.  Entrees were really really bad.  I had veal.  It was not tender and had what tasted like a bucket of salt on it.  Deserts were fine, but nothing special.  Overpriced even taking the view into consideration.  

I hate writing this review as the most special Day of my life occurred here.  I simply don't know how they can stay in business with quality and services levels consistently this low.  Not sure where our 23rd wedding anniversary will be, but it will no longer be the Le mont

(2nd star is only for nostalgia and memories of what used to be)

Our family visited Le Mont restaurant during the January 2017 Pittsburgh restaurant week. It's the best restaurant in Mount Washington we have ever visited. The food is the best. The service is great!

For starters- the view alone is worth a trip inside for dinner, drinks, or a late night appetizer and dessert. Since moving here I've wanted to give this place a try. We visited during restaurant week when the menu is more affordable and just select options are available. I'm extremely glad we gave it a try- it was fun to get dressed up, have an amazing view, and be waited on by some excellent servers. The con for me... the food just isn't that great! We paid a fraction of the price of the normal menu and I still was not close to blown away.  I don't think we will be back but I'm glad to have experienced it once.

Outstanding View and Average Food....

If you are visiting Pittsburgh, everyone will tell you to take the Incline and go up to the Mount Washington area and enjoy the beautiful view of downtown. 

We highly recommend going around sunset and find a table with a view at one of the restaurants on Mount Washington. We reserved a table at Le Mont for 5 PM and got a wonderful table with a view. As the sunset, the view began to change and it was spectacular. 

We ordered a seafood dish for the entree and it was average (in some ways considering the cost, below average). 

But we did have a good time enjoying the view from day time, thru sunset, all the way into the night.....

My review is for their wedding venue services as I recently had my reception at the LeMont and it was truly one of the greatest days of my life.

Prices were comparable to many other locations in the area, which surprised me as I always assumed the view alone would put the venue out of my price range. From the moment I walked into the reception room, I knew it was where I'd have my reception. I love the classy, old school decor and romantic feel to the space. The views cannot be beat and as we were having a good number of out of town guests, I wanted to show off Pittsburgh!

From our first meeting with Bill, the banquet manager, I knew we would be in good hands. His years of experience are evident and he was prompt with responses. There were a number of small details we requested and he always respoded: "don't worry, I'll take care of it" (place card table set up, "his and hers" whiskey glasses that we wanted to carry in with us at our entrance) - and it all got done! We were able to drop everything off the day before and they took care of the rest; it was so stress free! The set up of our reception exceeded my expectations thanks to the LeMont staff working alongside our other vendors.

Before the reception, the bridal party was able to use the cigar room until we were introduced. We were greeted right away by Bill and a member of the waitstaff, who truly treated us like it was our special day. They brought us all drinks right away and two trays of warm appetizers - the mushroom appetizer was delicious and the men all raved about the mini beef wellingtons and bacon-wrapped scallops. We got to enjoy a good 45 minutes with our bridal party before it was time for us to be introduced; it was so nice to be able to spend that intimate time with our bridal party and gave the men time to finish their celebration cigars! Out guests had a cocktail hour during this time, which must've gone well as everyone seemed energetic for our introductions.

The rest of the evening went off without a hitch - efficient dinner service and everything tasted just as it did for our taste testing. I was very impressed considering they had a packed valentines dining service on the top floor - it felt like we had the place to ourselves! The crab cakes were delicious and I could've eaten a plate of just those! I think our guests enjoyed their food, based on many empty plates. We stopped the bar during dinner and served their house wine instead, which the waitstaff were very prompt in refilling for our thirsty guests ;)

The dance floor was the perfect size and I was so pleased with how many guests were enjoying themselves! The downstairs reception area has a separate bar and sitting area, where we also set up a photo booth and our cookie tables, so our non-dancing guests were able to hang out there and talk. Even with close to 200 guests, I did not feel the space was overcrowded. My one concern with having my reception at the LeMont was that it may be a little "stuffy" but it was anything but that - we even extended the reception by an hour because our guests were having so much fun! We are still receiving compliments over a week later!

I could not have imagined a more perfect reception and cannot thank the staff of the LeMont enough for their kindness.

Pros: the view is breath taking, the service is impeccable, and the ambiance is romantic. 
Cons: the food just really isn't that great :(
I attended the Le Mont for the first time recently and was so excited to try out this classic Pittsburgh staple. The staff provided a wonderful experience, but honestly the food was just okay. Really glad I went, but not too sure I'll be back.

3.25 stars. But, I downgrade it to 3 because the care taken in preparing the food (and serving it) did not quite match what I would normally expect from an upscale restaurant like this. We had a very good experience with the scenery and the interior (and our conversation), but it could have been great if Le Mont went the extra mile and put in 100% effort into ingredients instead of building a foundation on iceberg lettuce. The food was basically average, not distinctive, and subpar at times. 

I have always been hesitant to try Le Mont (for the almost 3 years I have been in Pgh) due to somewhat mixed reviews, my fascination with the nearby Isabela which I always thought would be very hard to beat in romance, views, and relatively casual elegance, and, all right I will say it, the "old money" hunch I had of the place.  This hesitation was overcome last week when I wanted to treat some distinguished overseas visitors at a nice Mt. Washington eatery -- what place is better than Mt. Washington on a clear day to initiate an out-of-towner to Pittsburgh?

Le Mont is greatly successful in impressing visitors in two ways: outstanding scenery of the city and exquisitely decorated interiors. Sit at a table next to the window and enjoy the view both outside and inside. Deserves 5 stars easily for this. But that is 5 stars just for being at the right location at the right time. A great restaurant should do much more than that. 

The food and service are another story. From an upscale restaurant like Le Mont, I would have expected elegance in the food and ingredients that go into the food. The food was tasty, but it was lacking the fine care that is a staple of *great* restaurants. Let me explain. 

We ordered three appetizers: shrimp cocktail, crepes fontinia, and the oysters. Oysters were subpar, shrimp was not high quality and was served with iceberg like lettuce, crepes were just OK. Nothing was distinctive in the three dishes. The bottle of wine we got was very good, which made me somewhat forget, albeit temporarily, that the appetizers were average. The bread and butter were OK, but only with the cabernet my visitor chose. 

My swordfish entree was the best food I had, and it was actually good. The steak looked good, but I cannot vouch for it. A visitor had bouillabaise, which looked less soupy than what I think it is supposed to be, but he thought it was fine (maybe he was being polite).  

We did go all the way in and got desserts and coffee. I liked the carrot cake with cappuccino, but again nothing was really distinctive. 

Our main server, a gentleman who was clearly seasoned and confident in the art of waiting tables, was somewhat odd. He seemed he was always in a rush and was rough around the edges. I actually appreciated his experience and confidence (and even what could have been perceived as roughness), but I did not care much for the somewhat quick and rough service. Nonetheless, I enjoyed the service; it was fun, but I will for sure not call it elegant. 

To summarize:
+ Outstanding scenery and interiors
+ Good wine
- Average food, not necessarily prepared with great care
o Fun yet not-so-elegant service

Le Mont, thus, has great potential to improve and become an very good restaurant instead of an average one. I will probably give it another try at some point, but I would not take a date I am excited about to Le Mont.

Haven't been to lemont inxabout 10 years.  Was worried after seeing so many low rated reviews. Went with family during restaurant week. All of us loved the experience.   The food was delicious. .except for mashed potatoes.dry.   Filet melted in mouth..seafood appetizer tasty. .blue cheese dressing excellent. My sister loved the veal. View of city fabulous.  
Service was exceptional. .especially manager Dani..so friendly and professional. 
Will go back more often.
Kim F

First, I would like to thank YELP and the Le Mont for hosting this lovely event. This was my first visit and somehow I managed to enter through the back door! The staff helped direct me to the lounge. I considered having a drink except the bartenders were preoccupied when I tried to get their attention on a few occasions. 

Our event was held in a private room overlooking the city of Pittsburgh. Unbeatable view! The tables had impeccable settings which included plates emblazoned with the Le Mont name. Our server Dani was knowledgeable with 18 years of experience at the restaurant. 

I enjoyed both the white and red wines presented with our meal. 

The meal was average to me. I had a salad to start with house vinaigrette. As a main course I had the surf and turf. The steak was basic with no flavor and I felt a little embarrassed to ask my server for A1 steak sauce but everyone at the table said at least I didn't ask for ketchup! I would have liked the potatoes to be creamier and more cheesy. They were on the dry side. Half of my vegetables were undercooked while the other half was just right.

For dessert I had the funnel cake with pumpkin latte ice cream. There were 4 of these desserts presented to the table and none of them were plated in the same fashion. The cake was very hard and not a fresh funnel cake. The ice cream and whipped topping were the best part.

Overall it was a lovely evening meeting new people and I enjoyed the atmosphere.

This place has an awesome view, but the interior and the food is awful. I went here for a work party, (thank god i didn't come here and pay with my own money) and we were served selected items from the menu. My boyfriend and I both got the sea bass and it was literally the worst fish I have ever had dining out.  It was nothing but a semi-warm plain piece of fish with some seeds on top of it. There wasn't even any butter or sauce on it. The vegetables and sides also just tasted like they were boiled.  This was worse than even the banquet food I've had at weddings and other similar events.  The wallpaper was peeling off of the bathroom walls and the place was just ugly inside. The view is awesome, but not worth sitting through the disgusting meal i had.  There are much, much, much better restaurants in Pittsburgh in the same price range or even cheaper.

The view was fantastic. (I mean fantastic!)

The service was great. The waiter and bartender went out of their way to make sure we had everything we needed - not always easy when you are eating with a toddler! :) 

Then the food arrives. The soup of the day - Vichyssoise - was good, but unlike any I've ever had before. And that's where, for me, the good food stopped. The strawberry/prosciutto salad that I had was not good. Then, I had a chicken entree. I didn't even eat half. 

Nice evening out, great views, lackluster food.

Two stars for the view.  The lookout is beautiful and a perfect backdrop for a wedding reception.  The food... Well, it wasn't good.  So so bland.  The bread passed around was so so salty.  I couldn't eat it.  Something wasn't right about that bread.  The filet was so tough and tasteless.  They REALLY need to step it up when it comes to the food there.  That being said... I was at a wedding reception so maybe it's better in the dining room?

I love taking my friends and family to LeMont. The view and food are spectacular and there is no better way to show off the city of Pittsburgh. The staff is always friendly and goes above and beyond expectations. Keep up the good work.

Visited the restaurant on a date with a beautiful and sophisticated woman, so I really wanted to impress.  Parking was a bit of a challenge, but using valet quickly resolved that issue.  Once inside my date and I were immediately captivated by the view of the Pittsburgh skyline-- it is majestic!  BE AWARE--  when dining at Le  Mont. 1) do so in the evening. 2). Try and guarantee a table by the window.   

The restaurant has a very robust menu and wide selection of wines.  My waiter Marco was very courteous and knew exactly when to check on us--  as an ex-waiter I appreciated his professionalism.   My date and I were able to hold a virtually uninterrupted conversation.  

My only issue and reason for not giving place 4 stars.  --the bar area, where my date and sat.  Later in the evening it got very noisy with a somewhat rowdy crowd-- profane language and overall noisiness that really hurt the ambiance of the restaurant.  

I also must say the somewhat pricey menu may be do to the fact that your paying for a whole dining experience not just the food.

I recommend the restaurant but encourage anyone visiting the restaurant to reserve a window table in advance but be sure it is not near the bar area.

I think it's one of the best restaurants in the town. Class and elegance are synonyms of this place. The view is spectacular! Plus, they still have a live entertainment on the weekends. 
I cannot say that menu is too creative or thrilling, but also, I can't complain about the quality. Last time, I had swordfish and it was delicious. Plus, you can ask for substitute or to modify your order. The waiters are professional and attentive. 
Take your date here- it's very romantic ;)

This place is one of the most overrated restaurants in Pittsburgh. I'm glad to see that this isn't a highly rated spot based on Yelp reviews.  It's stuffy and way overpriced. All you're paying for is the view.

We attended this venue for a wedding and lets say I was so full I didnt eat the breakfast the next day. The venue was also beautiful with a great view.

Pros: 
-The view
-Valet parking
-Friendly Staff
-Food was good
-Drinks were great

Cons
-The filet mignon was over cooked and not the best quality meat
-Communication. When we arrived instead of directing the guests to the correct area they directed everyone to the cash bar because they weren't ready....when the bride and groom had paid for their guests to have open bar. A better option would have been to allow the guests to wait or make it clear that they would be responsible to pay for their drinks at the alternate bar.

I called to make a reservation. First time I called somehow I got hung up on. Second time I called it never connected to a receptionist! I just waited on the phone for 5 minutes then hung up. I'm taking my business elsewhere.

I have been here quite a few times. The most memorable was when we had our wedding reception here. We had it in the down stairs hall. The ambiance alone is beautiful, so adding your own little touches for your special day only makes it that much better. The bang for your buck is definitely worth it, and they have a variety of packages to choice from, as well as plenty of dishes to choose from. The view of the city, on a clear night, is very romantic for a date night. The dishes are pricey for dinner, but they are good. We have had a variety of their dishes and have yet to complain. Next time we go I will review, in detail, the dishes we have with pics.

The food is phenomenal. I had the raspberry duck and it was to die for. They had a live pianist and you overlooked the city of Pittsburgh, very romantic. The servers are dressed in suites. Dress to impress here, formal dining. Reservations are a must.

Came here after a long day at the NPC North American Championships (bodybuilding competition) as a triple date.  All three couples got the chateaubriand for two along with a variety or appetizers and different desserts.

The ambiance, food and service are AMAZING!  I am definitely a fan.  The place is upscale and formal, so lean towards the side of caution and dress either dress casual or formal with a jacket.  The venue is beautifully decorated with a stellar view both inside and outside of Pittsburgh.  There was a live band the night my partner and I were there with friends.  As per the food, from the appetizers to dessert, everything was perfect and down to the dot!  The serving size for appetizers are fair and entrees are generous.

For anyone seeking an intimate night with a loved one, Le Mont is definitely a place to consider.

I have lived in Pittsburgh for 25 years now and somehow I have never made it to Le Mont. Mostly because I have always thought it would be super expensive and didn't think I had a occasion fancy enough to eat there. I finally had the chance to go for a recent Yelp event and I have to say I will definitely be back soon!

Obviously we all know the view from Mt. Washington is amazing but it still blows your mind each and every time you see it. The view from this restaurant is simply breath taking. FYI little tip...press your camera directly up against the glass and you won't get a glare in your photos.

For the event I chose the salmon as my main entree and the creme brûlée for dessert. The salmon was absolutely amazing. Cooked absolutely perfectly and the almond crust on the outside was surprisingly very good with salmon. Something I wouldn't have typically considered pairing with salmon. The creme brûlée was also amazing! As creme brûlée almost always is. The sugar layer on top could have been a little harder like your typical creme brûlée though.

As for the service, it was phenomenal. All of the staff was very tentative and very professional at all times. After my wonderful experience I will definitely be back very soon!
The snail appetizer was succulent.  The view of the city, beautiful.

Beautiful views but the food was incredibly disappointing.  I wish I could report differently...

After scoping out the restaurant week menus, we decided to try the breathtaking views of the LeMont on Mt. Washington.   Dining there for $35.15 is a steal compared to their $60 Porterhouse.  For half the price our food was half the quality... if that.

Let me say the service was stellar and the ambiance,  though dated, was lovely.  They must have forgot how to cook over the years.

J ordered the Filet medallions medium rare.  What he received was gray meat, no sear, and purple in the middle.  His comment?  Looks like I'm hitting McDonald's on the way home.

A ordered the swordfish that was cooked well done.  Hmm perhaps the dishes were switched?

R had the veal and was underwhelmed at his entrée. 

Me?  Chicken Romano.  Broccoli was yellow, not a steamed green.  The breaded chicken was mush because it was saturated with something.  The potatoes had no seasoning at all.  Pass the salt!  And my chicken was dry... yet coated in moisture. 

Dessert was just as lackluster.  Who serves a creme Brule that isn't bruled?  It looked like last night's leftovers.  

The strawberry shortcake was coated in a strawberry drizzle that tasted like it was fresh from the container at the grocery store... the one that you put in milk and sundaes.

I realize that by offering restaurant week deals, we may not get the LeMont's finest, but we are paying patrons too.  And no, we will not be returning.  Not even for the view.  There are far better restaurants on Mt. Washington who offer views and delicious meals to ALL patrons.

I was sadly disappointed with my recent experience at The Le Mont. While the view of Pittsburgh during dinner has to be one of the best, the food in no way my expectations in light of how this restaurant is promoted as a fancier high class place. I don't mind paying more for good food, I just wish the food here was worth the price paid. 

My Caesar salad was soggy with too much dressing. After it was finally served to me, my husband realized it had even sitting on a serving tray behind us for 15 minutes.
This certainly explains the sogginess. My chicken saltimbocca deserves no higher rating than a 2/5. I could easily reproduce it myself, which is not a good sign. It wasn't that it was overcooked, but lacked flavor and had some sort of strange breaded exterior that was hard as a rock. Mashed potatoes were completely dry and bland. The lobster bisque also lacked flavor and contained about 2 pieces of lobster. I think I have had better soup from a can. 

The phenomenal view of Pittsburgh, especially at night, is the only thing that caused me to give this review a 3 instead of a 2 overall. But for me, even the great atmosphere was tainted by a meal which seemed more like an afterthought.

I really wouldn't return here again by my own choice.

I had a 5-star experience here mainly because I came here on a Wednesday night, with a prearranged large party that was able to secure an excellent corner spot with floor to ceiling windows surrounding us on two sides. And also, we came here for restaurant week too so we had a 3-course meal for $30 (pre-tip and alcohol) which was amazing.

The View:
Here's a tip, the best time to come is right before the sun sets. It's like you get two shows for the price of one. The sun reflecting off the 3 rivers is amazing. Here's another tip, choose the seat that faces the window. Or if you brought someone here to impress, have both of you sit perpendicular to the window. Since a picture is a thousand words, check out my photos of the skyline from Lemont.

The Food:
For the reduced price restaurant week menu we still had an amazing selection. I started off with a soup, moved onto Filet Mignon medallions topped with shrimp and dessert was a baked alaska, charred fresh with a blowtorch by our tuxedo-ed waiters right by our tables. Everything I ate was to be expected from a fine dining establishment. Although, I think the restaurant week menu has gone downhill since the time I went back in 2009.

The Service:
Who doesn't want to be served by a man in a tuxedo?! Although my waiter was probably twice my age, he showed no signs of airs and made sure everything was great. Which it was!

Overall, I had a great meal, a great view, and did it all within a very reasonable price. Only downside? I wish I was there with a girl instead.

We ate Thanksgiving Dinner here 11/23/2017 1st sitting. First time ever eating out for Thanksgiving! The restaurant looks the same as it did 30 years ago, gold , glitzy and glamorus. It has been maintained well and very clean, I believe new owners bought it in the past 10 years. It was a buffet. There was a long line, had to wait about 10 min to get to the food. If they could do 2 tables of food it may be better then the last hour just have it on 1 table. Was hard for older people to stand that long and kind of hard to fill and hold 2 plates.
What a treat once you got your food and ate slowly! We got a window seat! What a view! Wonderful! Right in front of the Point in Pittsburgh!
We had an older gentleman for our waiter Bob, very polished, very professional but very nice. His mom lived with him and was home, I asked him to wish her Happy Thanksgiving before we left.
They served the traditional fixings the mashed potatoes were real, the sweet potatoes delicious, stuffing was good too, turkey right off the bone carved in front of you, gravy good. They also had cranberries whole and breadworks breads. They had prime rib our son said it was delicious, salmon, ham, salads, fresh fruit, pasta my husband said was delicious. there were other foods but you can only eat so much!! Deserts were to die for!! All good, homemmade somewhere, fresh. Pumpkin pie, cannolis, spice cake with good not too sweet cream cheese icning and carrot cake, chocolate cake, eclairs danish, you name it they served it. Coffee, tea and soft drinks were included. It was pricey per adult but the view wow! The food delicious! The service excellent! It's ok to splurge on special occassions on excellent quality!

Wow, talk about overrated. First and last time here. Stopped by the bar side for a hopeful few cocktails/appetizers as recommended by friends. The head female bartender could barely be bothered by us and at least 5 times walked by ignoring us after initial drink order, and it was not very busy. Not until additional male bartender we could order additional drink and food. Opted for the sliders and stuffed mushrooms. The mushrooms were delicious but the "sliders" were more like the size of regular burgers with many pieces of bones in them. A disappointing experience, should have gone to Monterrey Bay.

I have nothing but fond memories with friends and family dining at the Le Mont over the years. There's something about this restaurant that makes me feel happy and hopeful, blissful senses that go far beyond the quality of the delicious food. As you gaze upon the beauty of the cityscape while the sounds of elegant music and laughter cascades in the background, you enjoy a masterfully prepared meal with the one(s) you love, and in that moment, you are reminded of how lucky you are to be there. The Le Mont is more than just an expensive meal, it's an experience - a memory - and for everyone, I hope it's a positive one. If you ever have the opportunity to see life from this perspective, regardless of your economical status, do so. I promise, you won't regret it.

I visited Le Mont for a wedding. 

Unbeatable view of Pittsburgh- both looking out to the beautiful landscape and looking in at my dear friends deciding to spend forever together. 

Drinks were strong and service was fine.

Quite possibly the worst wedding food I've ever had though, and that's saying something.

The view is great - that's the only thing nice I can say about this restaurant. The decor is faded and outdated. The food is definitely mediocre. My prime rib was overdone and over salted. The vegetables tasted as though they were dumped out of a can. The service was mediocre at best - our water glasses and bread were never refreshed. The staff definitely gave the impression that you were honored to be served by them. WAY overpriced....go to Altius or Vue 412. The food is much better, the service is exemplary, and the view is the same.

The name of this place is simply "Le Mont."  How do I know?  I used to live right next door!  It is an elegant restaurant up on Mt. Washington with an incredible view overlooking the three rivers that the old Steelers Three Rivers Football Stadium was named after:  Ohio, Allegheny & the Monongahela Rivers.  From up here you can see into the new Heinz Field!  Across the rivers is the new Pirates Baseball Stadium and the golden triangle of downtown Pittsburgh and bridge after bridge.  The food is expensive, but worth it and the view is unbelievable.  Be sure you make reservations, because you are not the only person who wants to eat here.  Do it in advance so you can sit by the windows.  Go on a fireworks night . . . or when the Inland Regatta is happening . . . or during football or baseball season.  Ride the tram up from below . . This is the place to be . . . . you will not be disappointed.

My wife and I went to Le Mont for our one year anniversary, being transplants to Pittsburgh and having been informed that this was the most romantic spot in town. The view of the city is delicious, but the view inside is extremely dated. The big, ornate chandeliers and trim on the walls would be fine if it were current, but the place seems a couple decades past it's prime. The service was excellent (very friendly, not pretentious), and the food was pretty good, although very overpriced in the general scheme of things. The maitre'd was quite rude when we intentionally showed up early, and told him we were there but would be taking a pre-dinner cocktail in the bar. His motivations are still unknown to us. All in all, it is probably better to spend this kind of scratch elsewhere.
Best filet I have ever had.  Other dinners and service were great.  Good meeting and conference destination

I've heard of LeMont and passed it a few times over the years but a Yelp event led me to finally stopping in. Before visiting I assumed LeMont was expensive, small portioned, and super fancy. Two of those things were false as LeMont was fancy as ever. I enjoyed how proactive the staff was and how favorable the food was. While there I had the broccoli cheddar soup which was the perfect way to start my meal and the pumpkin flavored ravioli was surprisingly amazing. The pecans gave it a nice flare. The show stopper here was hands down the funnel cake a'la mode with pumpkin spice ice cream. The funnel cake had a crunchy outside and a fluffy inside. It was the perfect balance of pumpkin and sweetness. The prices are pretty adorable and I will definitely be back in the future. As this is more than dinner with a view but it's an experience.

I had a great time going up to Mt. Washington and experiencing the view from the Le Mont. OMG. What an impressive view, what impressive service, and yum impressive food. I really think that this made me want to come back and honestly I have been telling people all about it since I left. And that $38 dollar special menu. WOWZA you cannot say no to that!

So you walk in and you are surrounded by Christmas trees. And are welcomed by the host right away. You can either check your coat or take it with you. Since I was running a bit late (obviously) I opted to keep my coat with me. I was then escorted to the back area where I was seated. 

The staff was so fast and efficient. The manager Dani who has been there for over 18 years told us that the staff have been there, some, over 30! That is crazy but these people really knew what they were doing. The table was beautifully decorated and had white and red wine already poured. The bread then was brought to the table and it was a basket of different types of bread. Yum. 

Main Course:
I started with a garden salad with the house dressing. The dressing was very good and it wasn't overly poured as to soak the lettuce. I was happy that they went light on the dressing so I could enjoy the meal. The salad was nice and a good little starter.

Then I enjoyed the surf and turf. I mean I licked my plate clean. The steak was done so tenderly that I didn't even need to use a knife if I didn't want. The turf was two jumbo shrimps that were skewered and buttered. The plate had a side of buttered goodness in a little dish that could be used to dip in the shrimp or the mashed potatoes. Now, those mashed potatoes.... They were fluffy and made into a little mountain. You almost didn't want to eat them since they were so pretty. The other side was then some broccolini and some other mixed veggies. It was really good and I ate everything on my plate. The plate was seasoned to perfection and nothing about it was bad. 

Dessert:
I got the creme brulee for the dessert portion of my meal. I will say that aesthetically it was very pleasing but the brulee was not like anything I have ever tried. Brulee is my favorite dessert so I have tried it a lot of times. This one did not have the crunch that most brulee has. It was more sugary at the top, like it was not flamed enough for the crust to form. It was still good, totally yummy, but not like I was thinking it would be. 

Overall, I love it. I want to go back and I want to try more of the menu. I think that this place really could be a fun place to go and I look forward to bringing some people the next time I want to go out to Mt. Washington.

This is one of my all time favorite places to dine. I love the opulent décor, incredible view, classic menu and the high level of service. 
Tonight's visit to Le Mont for my Birthday celebration has me feeling a little disappointed, and  I certainly hope the management can fix these few minor things and bring the 
dining experience back to  5 stars.
  The first thing I noticed when I arrived was the lighting on the stairs from the entranceway to the dining level. It is only a couple of short steps, but they are very wide.
The lighting under the steps looks to be a bargain basement LED strip lighting that was obviously incorrectly installed. It was hanging down, shining in the customers faces and the color was all wrong. It was a bright white LED hue that would be used in Walmart or in a basement workshop. I cannot believe that the management actually accepted this light installation from the get go. It may seem like a small detail, but it completely destroys the initial mood when you arrive. I have included a photo.

  The Le Mont salad was very tasty, except the dressing was a bit sharp. My Pork Chop, while tender and very lean, was rather bland. The cherry / apple glaze did not penetrate the meat enough to give it any deep flavor. Risotto was excellent as well as the vegetables. My dining companions meals looked and I was told were excellent, they ordered the Scallops and the prime rib.

We ordered the Cherries jubilee, which was excellent, but I noticed that the server preparing the dish tableside opened a sugar packet to sweeten the sauce. I would have expected a small ramekin of the required sugar to be on the tray, not a  5 cent sugar packet. Very tacky.

A few other small issues were that the live band was a bit too loud for fine dining, the wallpaper in the men's room upstairs was peeling, the print on the menu was too small for such a dimly lit area and those lights on the entrance stairs... my god ...simply unacceptable.
  My opinion is that it's still a great place to dine, but some of the edges are getting a bit rough. It is the small things that add up to make the whole experience complete.

Haven't been to Lemont in many a year!  Always liked the food and service was impeccable!   Well it hasn't changed!

The maitre'd showed our small group to a great table in the corner.  Yes!, what a great view!  Had reservations for a friends birthday...special occasion.  Fun to watch boats on the river, the incline and planes flying over the Northside..oh excuse me, it is now the North Shore.  We did go mid-week so it was not crowded.

We had a few kids, ages 11 to 14, and the maitre'd and server were so good at making sure they could order just about anything they wanted.  They had a long list of ideas not on the menu, since everything is made to order.  Fantastic!  Server went way above and beyond, like you would expect at a top notch restaurant.

The tables were so sweet!  Shiny table ware and glasses.  Fancy plates and linens, it is nice to dine out.  We ordered some Champagne to start off and waiter made sure to ask about the type we preferred, Brut, Asti or semi???  Great job!

Server also suggested we not over order apps, and extras and told us about the roasted tomato that came with our meal.  Started with a couple of apps, escargot alio was so nice with garlic, not seen much anymore but fun to see the kids try!  The crepes fontinia were delicious.

Had a classic, the Lemont salad, nice fresh greens served with the Lemont vinaigrete, really enjoyable.  

The meal came with assorted fresh bread and was refilled when needed.

Had the Veal loin rib chop for two that was cooked perfectly, tender and sweet.  Others had the salmon, New York Strip steak and a special kids spaghetti. Everyone loved their meals and how they were cooked. Managed to get a bite of the spaghetti when the young one next to me keep saying this is better than grandmom's.  It was very good indeed.

When you go you have to try the deserts.  We decided to get a couple of the old tried and true cooked tableside so the kids, big kids too, could watch and try deserts they have never seen.  The Baked Alaska and Bananas Foster were sweet and very good, as was the coconut cake.  Deserts were passed around and the Bananas were the fav.

Lemont can be a little pricey if you order extras, but not to bad if you stick to the basics, but  you get really good food and service.  This is a top notch place during the week.  

What a great experience!

Chandeliers and men in tuxedos, do not equal 'good food'. 
The dishes tasted like the most basic catered wedding food. I imagine the cook only knows of two seasonings, salt and pepper; both were used sparingly. The dessert tray resembled cakes from a diner display case, not the expensively priced sugar prizes they were purported to be. Good place for grandparents or anyone who considers mini gerkins on toothpicks to be the height of sophistication.

We went here for our honeymoon on Sunday night. I'm not sure if they have altered things since their current poor reviews. We were accommodated as we changed our reservation time twice. We arrived ten minutes early, and we're immediately seated. Danny seated us and was very pleasant. Our server Mike was easy to find throughout the evening, and very entertaining. Maybe people think it's slow because they finished our courses table side. We ordered Caesar salad,  chateaubriand for two, and bananas foster. All were superb!

The LeMont is great for celebrating special occasions. Yes its expensive, but for a special occasion its worth it! Delicious menu, good portion sizes and quality buffet dinners. Spectacular view- maybe even the best in the city! There are lots of window seats too! Nice cocktail selection, each made with high quality ingredients and nicely balanced. With a view like that and the ornate decor, your celebrating your special occasion in style!

We had something to celebrate so where else would we go in Pittsburgh? The atmosphere lends to the celebration and made my sister feel so special for graduating college. It's the perfect place to go to welcome her to the adult world. But my 17-month old son wasn't out of place, which isn't what I expected! The staff was very friendly to him and there was a changing table in the bathroom for him, plus a high chair. 

I had the veal and shrimp Romano piccata and it was delicious. The rest of the party had the filet mignon and one person had the crab cakes. Everyone loved their meals. I also had the table side ceased salad which felt decadent. And speaking of, the carrot cake for dessert was a perfect end to my meal. 

I was happy that we were seated by the window bc duh, that's what we were there for. The view was just out of this world, of course. 

I do wish the valet pulled right up to the door at the end of the night. This might seem stupid to complain, but why should I cross the street to get the car as it pulls out of the parking lot? I could have done that myself without paying $6 + tip.

Attended a gala last night downstairs. There was this woman working and she went out of her way to make sure I had a plant friendly meal. She was so friendly and quickly took it upon herself to help me out. They brought me a steaming plate of yummy freshly steamed veggies. They were super yummy and I couldn't have been happier!

Wow, the views from Le Mont are truly breathtaking. I came for an event recently and the room had floor to ceiling windows with a beautiful view of Pittsburgh. We were started with salad and bread. For the main course, I had the chicken bruschetta with potatoes and green beans. The chicken was breaded with a balsamic vinaigrette sauce. The service was excellent as well. The event was held to the left of the main dining room and was very spacious. There was room to walk around and mingle and there was a dance floor as well. The whole restaurant has a very grand feeling to it. Even as someone from Pittsburgh, I still appreciated the views!

Growing up a Yinzer, I always thought that the Le Mont was too pricey an'nat just to see a view of dawntawn Pixburg.  Well say hello to the Le Mont fixed price menu (or as they say the "prix-fixe menu").  For $50, yes $50, you get two main dishes and two-side salads.  This special coincides with the restaurant celebrating 50 years of service.  True, as prior reviewers have stated, the place does feel a little like a high-class place from the eighties but if you order off this menu, you will definitely get your monies worth and have a very nice experience.

Atmosphere - Think fancy restaurant from any 1980's movie where someone creates a scene and everyone is shocked...saying things like "oh, my".  

Service - Friendly, prompt, first rate.

Food - I ordered from the prix-fixe menu and ordered the...actually, I forget the exact name of the dish...but it was the one with two 4 oz fillets.  They have several other choices including fish.  It, my fillets, were prepared as ordered, medium, and they were delicious even with a brown sauce drizzled on top.  Oh, the darn French and their nonstop use of sauces make for watching your weight difficult.  The Lemont salad that was part of the meal deal was basic and good as were the accompanying breads.  For dessert, I had the coconut custard cake, which was also very good and moist!   

Price - Um,...$50 for two.  Where they get you is on the dessert and drinks.  The dessert was $7 and drinks are priced at restaurant drink rates...yeah known...expensive.  Although they do have a list of select wines at $25 a bottle, which can work well on a budget.  

Overall - I think with this promo, the Le Mont is one of the best deals in town.  So, go check it out an'nat.

Note: I went on a weekday, not positive if the prix-fixe menu is available on weekends.

Ambience is Fabulous. We ordered off the 50 year anniversary menu and both dinners were disappointing. Our waiter gave us complimentary desserts. We danced, that was special. We will be back but we will not order off the anniversary menu.

We had a gift card to Le Mont but didn't get to go there until the day before the expiration. Whoops. Made a reservation for 8pm on a Friday night. Rolled up to the front and got our car parked through the valet. When we entered, you could feel the opulence reeking out from the decor but in an old school way. The host was kind but unfortunately sandwiched us into this corner in between two large parties. The view was fantastic though. We were served bread and the candle was lit on our table but then because of where we were located, blending in with the two parties, we had to wave down a waitstaff for a menu after twenty minutes. They apologized profusely and offered a glass of wine on the house. This was kind of them though I was not impressed with their wine menu. I am not a wine expert at all but when you've got Sutter Home at $8 per glass it does make me wonder... I ordered a caesar salad to start which was made table side and then had the raspberry duck. Both were delicious and they redeemed themselves on the starter and entree. Then we ordered bananas foster for dessert which was made table side like the salad and the portion was huge but very delicious. I wish I had more room to eat it! These too were on the house because of the delay that we experienced. All in all the food was good and the wait staff were great but the style of Le Mont was just not me so I probably would not come back unless there was a specific reason.

The view, while spectacular, could never aspire to compensate for the horrendously expensive and bland food. The salmon was overcooked and they even managed to botch the chicken. The accompanying side carrots and green beans were a cruel joke. 2 stars for the service and decor, but they should seriously rethink their kitchen.

Le Mont just lost $30,000 tonight.

Me, my fiancé, and her mother went to Le Mont for dinner tonight in hopes of locking down a date for our wedding venue next year. Well, I definitely would have thrown my money at them if I wanted countless disappointing memories and an over the top, pretentious, unprofessional, outdated venue.

Le Mont reminds me of a restaurant that made it big in the past with presumably good food, service, and professionalism while of course being complemented by the unmatched view of Pittsburgh. However, complacency must have set in because all of those characteristics were lost along the way.

Upon arrival, we were not greeted with even a hello. We were standing waiting for our table while one of the staff members motioned over to us (while standing deep within the restaurant) to come follow him. If it wasn't for my fiancé paying attention his efforts would have been useless, while remaining devoid of professionalism.

Our waitor clearly lacked proper training for a place of this caliber. Nothing against him, but if you work hard during the week to go to a restaurant and pay hundreds of dollars for dinner, you would like a waitor that is professional, knowledgeable about the menu, and attentive. For example, he asked me if I would like another cocktail as it was 3/4 finished. I said yes as I proceeded to finish it; meanwhile he waited behind me as I finished the drink and said: "Oh I'm just waiting for you to finish so I can make you another drink in the same glass." WHAT!??!!?

I ordered the filet mignon and said I wanted it between medium and medium rare. His response: "Well I'll just have them cook it medium rare and if it's undercooked for you I'll have them cook it a little bit more." WHAT!??!!

The side vegetables were 100% frozen and just came out of the microwave, and lacked any effort of seasoning to help disguise its origin, the grocery store shelf.

When it was time for dessert, they brought out a food cart of half eaten cakes that looked like they had been raided by a hungry pack of wolves. But, in any attempt to salvage the night, me and my fiancés mother ordered a slice of cake. The waitor asked my fiance if she wanted anything and she said no because she was full. His response: "You sure you don't want nuttin?" WHAT!??! 

I ordered a cappuccino which lacked foam and had burnt coffee inside. To top it off, the plate was "beautifully garnished" with a shriveled, small, dirty, lemon peel. "Yes, I love lemon with my coffee." When I confronted the waitor about it, he indeed confirmed that it was a garnish. WHAT?!?!?!?!!? 

The bathrooms were dirty, floors were sticky, wall paper was peeling, and outdated. On the way out, no "have a good night, thank you for coming, etc" was said. Pretty fitting though - with this poor excuse for a 5 star restaurant I would expect nothing more: lack of professionalism, mediocre precooked food, and ridiculous comments about lemon peels, but definite willingness to take your money.

STAY AWAY FROM THIS RESTAURANT. IT NEEDS GORDON RAMSEY, OR A BULLDOZER. SPEND YOUR HARD EARNED MONEY ELSEWHERE.

JUST GOOGLE THE VIEW.

The ambiance of this place really sets the tone for a great gastronomic experience. The tall ceilings, crown moulding, beautiful chandeliers and opulent environment was just beautiful. The prix fix menu was very generous for the price point. The cocktail menu was great. The cucumber martini was delicious and satisfying. The veal roulade was beautiful. The seafood it was filled with was impressive but a bit poorly executed. Several of the shellfish were not prepped well. For instance the shrimp still had shells on. I wouldn't expect to find that in a roulade. The flavor was good. The roasted pepper tomato soup was delicious. The Caesar salad was perfect! The rib eye was cooked one level higher than what I ordered but was still very tender and juicy. If ordering steak, order one level less cooked than what you fancy and you will get what you want. The fruit/vinegar compote on top of the steak was absolutely unnecessary. It totally violated the beauty of that steak. On its own, it was a delicious accompaniment but smothering the steak with it was just wrong. The table side foster dessert was a great display of showmanship on the part of our waitress who was also very good. Overall this was a memorable experience and I definitely will consider coming back here the next time I'm in Pittsburgh.

We came here for Easter brunch and I was expecting a lot. I've grown up with everyone in the area talking about how great and fancy the Le Mont is. Well, I'll tell you this much.. Never go to this over priced brunch Buffett. We had terrible service from some some gentleman and we were left with empty drinks and trying to figure out where the buffet stations were. The food was cold on the buffet even! The best part was the cheesecake, that was delicious. The view is gorgeous as well, but you can get that for free from the Mt Washington lookouts. Maybe their regular meals are better, but I have no desire to even try.

Went to the LeMont years ago and it was great. Went back again to treat my parents for their anniversary. We had booked a table for 4 at a window at 6 pm. We had a table in the central part of the restaurant  and had to wait until 7 to be seated. The guy that seated us said that I must have forgotten to request a window seat and was rather condescending.  The food tasted like pre-made food from a freezer. I knew it would be expensive but the quality was so bad. I recently went back because a friend insisted and it was like no time had ever past. The food was terrible and cold in an uneven way like it was microwaved and tasted so bland. Go up the incline and then go somewhere else better, like McDs for food. The only thing that was good was my desert.

I agree with other reviewers and say that you pay for the view here but also the food. I think the food is absolutely yummy! I came here for the PRISM international student ministry dinner tonight and my oh my, the balsamic chicken and veggies were divine. The waiters and waitresses here act a bit annoyed at their jobs, so I also agree that the service is so-so. I think they might have a better time watching paint dry.....but anyhoo. 

On to the dessert: imagine a perfectly round ball of ice cream dipped in the perfect amount of crushed oreo crumbs that cover every square inch of the ice cream. Now top that with fudge. Dangit, you got yourself a deal. Every eye at the table bulged with fattened glory at this heavenly sweet. I want another oreo ball right now.

Also, not only did we get to see the perfect spring evening but topped off the night with an amazing lightning show with heavy rain shower. Can't beat that view of the city!

They out did themselves tonight I had the pork chop with an apple walnut glaze, that was delicious the wait staff was on point, with just enough to know when to come by and when to wait until I was ready.. It's always a pleasure to come here..

We dined here with some trepidation due to what previous reviewers had posted.  But we were visiting someone who really wanted the experience, so we reserved a table and prepared ourselves to enjoy the view but to be disappointed in the meal.

We were wrong.  Le Mont's view is,to be sure, the best you will find of downtown Pittsburgh and its waterfront at night, but the food also stands on its own merits. Our group dined on steak and lamb, and all were pleased with their fare.  Entrees were all cooked as ordered and the vegetable accompanyments were all fresh, cooked to showcase the taste of the vegetable (Carrots and asparagus), and presented in a well-plated manner.

Salads all came out well, with fresh greens enhanced (not smothered) by the dressings.  Dessert and coffee satisfied as well.

We give five stars for the view, four stars for the excellent service from Maitre d' and wait staff, and the food gets a solid three stars which probably should have been four stars if we could have tasted some of the dishes we did not order that wes aw coming our from the kitchen.

Live caberet music enhanced our evening.  Valet parking was easyand worth the charge.

Having come in with a skeptical mind, we all left very satisfied.  We will dine here again.

I've been here many times over the years for dinners, parties and other events. I'm a freelance journalist and a magazine I wrote for held a launch party here. The most incredible things are the views of the city and the interior. Simply spectacular. What's not so spectacular is the food and at times the service. It's kinda joe the Grand Concourse is now. Sometimes the food is fantastic sometimes it's bland. Sometimes service is good and sometimes it's not. These types of places don't really seem to change to keep up with the times.

The LeMont on top of Mt.Washington overlooking the city has a charming atmosphere where you can spend several hours enjoying a delicious dinner. The staff is friendly and makes every attempt to make your evening special. Marco is a waiter extraordinaire. Perhaps the best in the business! The view of the city is fantastic, especially after sundown.

What a glamorous view of Pittsburgh!  I came here with a Party of 10 to celebrate a friends birthday we had made reservations for.  

Restaurant: The restaurant itself was bustling and busy as it was holiday party season.  Yes it's dated glam but still very glam, classic Victorian even...I really find anything wrong with it like other posters.  

Food: Anyone coming here should expect to overpay for your meal, so no shockers there.  Get the French Onion Soup, cream of the crop there!  A few of us ordered the Filet Steaks that ordinary come wrapped in bacon but every single person at our table who ordered specified no bacon.  Come entree time, a few didn't have bacon but a few did so we had to send them back.  You could also tell they just unwrapped the bacon from the steak and returned it to us, not actually preparing a new Filet.  Furthermore my Filet was requested Medium and it arrived Medium Rare.  By the time I sent it back and they recooked it, we were serving cake so I didn't eat it. A disappointment for a restaurant of this class.  

Service: For a high class establishment, I would suggest the male server not hit on guests, even kindly....that's just not professional.  Our main female server was very kind even though you could tell it was a very busy night for her.  She should have payed closer attention to the dietary restrictions of the group though.

Come back? - Eh its worth going to, maybe again next year.

Le Mont or should I say "the le mont" like my yinzer brethren is what you would expect it to be if you are from this town.  Now, if you are from out of town it is truly one of he most beautiful vistas you can see whlle dining in any city.  I've eaten here maybe a dozen times and a few years ago hosted about 30 nights while presenting seminars.  As an aside this is a good spot for business functions because it has good name recognition, professional staff and a restaurant manager who will negotiate costs.  Anyways, I was here again on Monday and the fact that we were there probably dropped the average age a few decades, which is fine.  This is definitely the kind of place your parents and grandparents would like.   It was a Monday and at first when we were cocktailing at the bar seemed relatively empty, but actually to my surprise filled up through the evening with elegant gents and ladies wearing there sunday or monday best'.  The restaurant itself is classically elegant.  BIg beautiful chandeliers, lots of ornate woodwork and crystal, bold colors and a baby grand' elevated above the dance floor.  After a guinness (bonus) at the bar we were seated at a big table right on the glass.  The view was sublime, however there were a few dead flies on the inside ledge a few inches from where we were seated.  The waiter was there quickly to get our drink orders and explain the features.  He was a professional server and was pretty much spot on from start to finish.  The features of course, were seafood (restaurant trying to clear out leftover seafood from the weekend) there was a platter with lobster tail, coquille, and a few other items.  I didn't try it, but Garrett and Tom said it was good, I'm sure the quality wasn't that great, but it was a large portion.  We started with a few apps'.  They were calamari (nothing special, overpriced at $13), also the brie (chambord brie stuffed with apricots, apples and pecans finished with an apple glaze).  This was pretty delish, but at $14 again a bit high and the final app' was oysters bienville (oysters topped with asiago, crab and spinach).  This was okay, but again the same theme here overpriced for quality.  A few folks had the ceaser salad which was fun because it was prepared tableside.  I was told it was very good.  Megan got some chicken dish with pineapple.  It looked pretty good and not dry.  Tom and Keith had some type of preperation of veal, which they both said was excellent served with perfectly cooked root vegetables and mashed potatoes.  Matt had the steak diane, which is fun again because it's two small filets prepared tableside with a nice demi-glaze.  I had the lamb which were several small lamb chops lightly breaded with a mustard type glaze and breading.  It was okay and I will admit I ate all of it, however it was a bit more "gamey" than it should have been.  There were several desserts sampled and most were palatable.  Megan tried some coffee at the end, however the cream was spoiled.  THe waiter quickly replaced.  This is a place you should take out of town guests, however if it's my "dime", which it usually isn't when I'm here you can do better elsewhere.  You are easily paying a 20% premium for the view and it is pretty much the opposite of "hip or trendy", which isn't necessarily a bad thing.  The service is 4 stars, the food 2 stars or less because of price, but the view is 5 stars.  Go at least once and sadly that's probably enough.

I just got married at The Le Mont in March and they did a fantastic job! Bill is awesome and does an outstanding job to accommodate. I went with The Le Mont because I used to be a wedding planner in Pittsburgh before moving to the west coast and I trust them every time! They are like a well oiled machine of caterers and staff. All the times I have worked the venues I have seem the same people event after event. They know what they are doing and how to make a wedding run smoothly! 
The food was fantastic and the view is unbeatable! I wish I could do it all over again :)

The perfect spot for an elegant night. Wonderful view, decedent food, kind staff. The wine list was well curated but I wasn't a fan of it being printed on orange paper. I realize that's extremely picky. It was a perfect experience and we will be back again soon.

I love the view, and the atmosphere at the Le Mont. The restaurant is just simply beautiful especially decorated for the holidays.  The Autumn celebration menu is such an amazing deal.  I ordered the broccoli cheddar soup, butternut pumpkin ravioli, and the funnel cake with pumpkin ice cream.  Its a steal for $38, and a lot of food. The ravioli is the best I've ever had and I highly recommend this dish. Also, the restaurant was very clean and the service was great.  We will be back for sure to try something off the Winter celebration menu.

Absolutely fantastic. Family favorite.  Amazing meals. Provides patrons with distinctly different evenings that cater to individual needs. From romantic evenings- to family meals with young children- to business dinners- to specialized events- it's always a superb experience . The staff is fantastic yet warm. True representatives of the personality of this city. 

I'm partial to eating in the dining room for a slow multi course meal. However, the lounge options are a nice way to relax and grab some casual bites. Often the space has live music. Easily, a couple can relax and enjoy a night in the Lounge spending about $50., yet feel like the bill should have been much higher. A real deal considering the quality of items served.  

Overall, you get much more than you pay for. Yes, it's far from inexpensive however they always hit their mark and offer more than I anticipate. 

Best tip- don't overlook the vegetable streusel.  Fabulous. Also- share your food preferences. Staff makes suggestions and tweaks any menu item to suite your tastes.

One important thing- don't forget to save room for dessert. Cutting back on amazing salads and soups, then entrees that melt in your mouth is difficult. The desserts and after dinner coffee's, they shouldn't be missed.
